reviewText: When I heard about IDIOCRACY, I had high hopes. I really did.Mike Judge is brilliant-- from B&B; to KOTH to Office Space, the guy's great.So I bought IDIOCRACY and watched it.I'm disappointed.The premise sounds great on paper-- intelligence gives up without a whimper, drowned in the gene pool by overbreeding hillbillies and gangbangers who accelerate our pop culture's race to the bottom-- but it doesn't provide much fertile ground for making jokes. Basically, we're shown this lousy future and... that's it.Joe (Luke Wilson) and Rita (Maya Rudolph) are average non-entities who become the smartest people in the world-- even though they aren't exceptional in any way; he's a slacker Army librarian and she's a hooker for a pimp named Upgrayyd.Ha... ha... ha.We see a miserable future where all-around idiot Frito (Dax Shepard) is a lawyer (or "attornee" as his jacket sleeve insists), who rants *against* his client at his trial (overseen by a judge played by Judge stalwart Stephen Root) and ensures his conviction and entry into "Monday Night Rehabilitation"-- that is, gladiatorial games for the terminally dumb.Why not have characters against which Joe and Rita play off? A hidden enclave of "smarties" struggling to keep a feeble flicker of intelligence alive, or a gung-ho Marine from their time who's out-macho'ed by the brawn-worshipping braindead of this future? But no.There are some clever sight gags but I felt the entire thing would have been more amusing as a series of skits-- like an ongoing Saturday Night Live bit-- than as a movie. The plot is never engaging, the acid tone of the "satire" chews through the jokes, and the performances are listless.If you're truly a Mike Judge fan... watch OFFICE SPACE again.

reviewText: I liked it, but I dare say it could have been better.The setup is interesting: an average man stuck in a land of idiots. I submit to you that Mike Judge may not have been warning us about the future, but rather making exagerations to express his view of our current state.  And if you really were a rare intelligent person stuck in a world of idiots, with no intelligent past to return to, what would you do?If this is what Judge wanted us to think, that makes it a 5-star movie with 2 subtracted for poor execution. reviewText: Mike Judge, director of the cult classic "Office Space" as well as the creator of TV's "Beavis & Butthead" and "King of the Hill," delivers perhaps his most outlandish and most imaginative work to date in "Idiocracy." Luke Wilson ("Old School") and Maya Rudolph ("Away We Go") play subjects of a military experiment gone wrong who find themselves waking up in the year 2505, when mankind has devolved to the point of uselessness and near-extinction, brought on by needless over-breeding, poor dietary choices and mind-numbing television. Wilson plays the slacker and Rudolph a prostitute, and both turn out to be the strongest and smartest in a world gone terribly, terribly wrong."Idiocracy" is the kind of wacky yet centered cautionary tale that only the mind of Mike Judge could produce, but unfortunately loses steam half way through when its narrative is given nowhere to go, giving way to a slightly clichéd Hollywood ending that doesn't quite gel with the overall tone of the rest of the movie. It's a shame that the film bogs itself down in simplicity when much of the material at hand is rife with social commentary and oh-so subtle jabs at its viewer as well as its production company, Twentieth Century Fox (who, in turn, abused the film so badly that it was an inevitable flop). There's heavy usage of CGI to convey a trash avalanche as well as a monster-truck jam of sorts that gives the movie an unintentionally cartoonish look and feel. Surprisingly, though, it works in the film's favor, giving the film a wacky tone when it could easily slide into gloomier territory. It also doesn't hurt to have left-field cameos from the likes of Justin Long, Stephen Root and Thomas Haden Church, either.In the end, it's a film with bold ideas that doesn't quite reach its potential. Still, though, like much of Judge's other work, it will have you thinking and questioning the world around you. Is "Idiocracy" ahead of the curve, foreshadowing the shape of things to come? Well, only time will tell. As for now, enjoy it for the sublimely ridiculous comedy that it is.

reviewText: Much has been said of the plot, where an average joe Army librarian and a prostitute are chosen for a military experiment and wake up 500 years later in an America in the midst of a new dark age of ignorance.For years, thinkers have glumly predicted that American would go the way of the Roman Empire. This is a visualization of that concept.The film is supposed to be a comedy, but I only cracked a smile once in the whole film (where Terry Crews as the wild man/president goes into black preacher mode in the midst of his "speech").For the most part, this is a very depressing tale of a "brave new world." The Idiocrats don't talk. They mumble monosyllables mixed with profanity and gutter slang. Garbage is strewn everywhere and ruins of skyscrapers and freeways abound. Corporate and commercial slogans replace conversation. Television and movies consist of pornography and "America's Favorite Videos" type violent segments. Slack jawed illiterate receptionists have picture buttons on all of their computers and cash registers, articulate speech is ridiculed as effeminate.Yeah I know. Sounds like now.At one point, the Army librarian (renamed "Not Sure" by the Idiocrats) is sentenced to death by said Idiocrats to be run over by monster trucks and a flamethrowing wrestler in an area on national television. A clear connection to Ancient Rome and the Gladiators.A major point that was not commented on is about 2/3 on in the story when the Army Librarian tells his 21st century comrade that they should go back in time to warn the people to read more, go to school, and activate their minds so that this kind of horrible future could be avoided.Hear hear. I am a teacher and like many in my profession, I fear the likelihood of a backward new dark age of a future like this. Let's work now America to keep exercising our brains so that this film does not become a reality.ADDENDUM-Incidentally, I recently has a chance to read the original screenplay online by Mike Judge. Those who consider this film to be bleak, depressing, and unfunny would not like the original intention of this film at all. That version is even scarier, angrier, more vulgar, and grimmer than this and is far less of a comedy than a nightmarish warning of things to come. Mike laid it on THICK. Really heavy-handed Jonathan Swift/George Orwell/Rod Serling type stuff. The Idiocrats in the script are far more savage and subhuman than in the film and the dovetailing of humanity into the Idiocrats is treated with more detail. However, aside from a few distractions such as the subplot of Joe/Not Sure's girlfriend and the museum scene (both of which are in the deleted scenes of the DVD), the original script is a tad more of a coherent story than the finished product. Some of the dialogue in the finished product (such as Joe/Not Sure's pontifications on the need to read and go to school and Terry Crews' speech where he uses the machine gun) is better than originally written. Basically, fans of this film who wonder about the clunky transitions in plot are missing a clearer, but for more depressing film than originally intended.

reviewText: Mike Judge's dystopic comedy (which was barely released by its studio) is only mildly funny. It opens in the present, with average guy Joe (Luke Wilson) drafted by the military for a hibernation project. He is supposed to wake up in a year, but because of a mishap, he wakes up 500 years from the present. There he finds a society populated by morons. It seems that the intelligent didn't breed as much as the unintelligent, and the result five centuries from now is a society of astonishing vulgarity and coarseness, in a state of terminal decline. Here one has to add that the scientific premise behind this conceit is shaky: thinkers have noted and worried for centuries that the poor and unintelligent are having more babies than the rich and intelligent. Yet, despite this, IQ scores throughout the world have gone up, a probable result of increased education (and a refutation of genetic determinism). The movie is also somewhat racist: is it supposed to be a sign of decline the fact that the US president is now a black with a hispanic surname?. The movie's better when it hits at the corporate world, who has taken over every aspect of this future society. All in all, an ambitious but not very accomplished movie.

reviewText: I suspect Mike Judge has read some science fiction in his time, and this film reminded me of a satiric short story by C.M. Kornbluth from the 1950's, "The Marching Morons," in which an average guy wakes up a thousand years in the future to find a world in which a very few smart people keep the world going for a whole lot of dumb people.  In Mike Judge's Idiocracy, an average guy and an average woman wake up in the future to find there are no smart people at all.  I really don't buy into the movie's premise that idiots have more children than smart people; if you follow that train of logic back 2000 years, every Roman must have been a genius.  Still, when you look around today, you have to wonder if something odd is going on.If you've noticed the sorry state of today's culture and worried about our increasingly dumbed down society, the movie often feels uncomfortably true and doesn't seem all that implausible.  I'm glad I'm not the only one who feels as if something's gone very wrong and that we're about to go over a cliff; obviously, Mike Judge feels that way too. Judge aims his satiric arrows at much of what's wrong with America in the 21st century;  rampant consumerism, bad TV, urban culture, irresponsibility, loud music, rudeness, and dumb people.  The movie skewers Fox News and Al Gore (who vocally resembles one of the 26th century morons) with equal relish.Luke Wilson is very good in the lead; he appropriately plays it perfectly seriously. I thought Terry Crews as the president was also quite funny. The DVD extras are not great, and the menu is cluttered, hard to navigate, and appears to have been designed by someone from the the 26th century.  The DVD would have benefited greatly from a director's commentary; this movie is well suited for that.This movie is a fascinating blend of a really smart premise with spottily successful low comedy. It aims high, often falls short of its target, but has plenty of laughs.  If you watch the movie and don't like it, you can always go to the Mall to buy some more stuff to make you feel better.

A prostitute named Rita (Maya Rudolph) is selected as the other subject, for reasons that are barely explained and play into a weak premise for the mishap catalyst.When Joe and Rita awake, they are 499 years further into the future than planned, and encounter an absurd dystopia as a result of society dumbing itself down and counter-productive breeding selection.  It is an interesting though oxymoronic society which is increasingly technologically advanced yet intellectually regressed.  Although the setting and premise strain credulity and are not logically plausible, it all makes for a very funny story and can be overlooked and/or forgiven.Joe starts out accidentally/mistakenly as a criminal, and is assigned a defense attorney named Frito Pendejo (Dax Shepard, in another great performance) who also happens to be the one who filed the charges against Joe.  To describe the situation as a conflict of interest is putting it very mildly, and Frito hilariously helps to convict Joe.  After a not-so-clever-but-effective escape from prison, Joe is a fugitive trying to get back to his own time period (and thus begins his search for the Time Machine).  Through a series of events also more humorous than clever, it is discovered that Joe is the smartest person in the country.  This begins his climb through the levels of government power, though with this also comes a great responsibility to save the country from its own titanic stupidity.The film makes a few points as a cynical social satire, though it prefers to establish itself more through relatively unsophisticated (but effective) humor than through thoughtful discourse.  As a social commentary, it is hugely exaggerated and recreational, though this is frankly preferable to the recent barrage of documentaries full of egocentric sanctimony purporting to be socially relevant principles.  The film should not be taken too seriously, and is not meant to be.  Mike Judge makes his point, but still decides to have fun with the film.  This movie probably deserves 3.5 stars, but nudged itself to 4 because of several great lines (the best one spoken by Justin Long in his brief but hilarious cameo appearance as a mentally deficient Doctor).  In all, a good movie to invite friends over and share some laughs with.

reviewText: In 1999 Mike Judge's "Office Space" was poorly promoted and made only an initial $800,000 at the box office. A weird thing happened however on the way to oblivion...the movie became a huge cultural hit once it appeared on DVD. It was such a smash that Judge was set to do another movie, "The United States of Uhh-merica" which would later become "Idiocracy". The irony here is that "Idiocracy" was also not supported by the studios, being released in only a few cities with little to no promotion. It failed, of course, and has been recently released onto DVD.So will lighting strike twice? Maybe, the movie is better than it's initial reception alludes to but it's not as consistent or as witty as "Office Space". The premise is broad but funny, society is de-evolving. Over the next 500 years dumber families will have more kids than smarter families ultimately sinking the accumulative IQ average down to record lows. So in the future, people's favorite TV show will be "Oh... My Balls!" and sports drink will replace water entirely. Enter Joe Bauers an average army Joe who "volunteers" for a suspended animation program; he and  another women from the early 21st century arise in the 26th century after a freak mishap. As a result Joe Bauers is now the smartest man on earth, which may not be as cool as it sounds.The comedy is more a kin to "Beavis and Butthead" than to "The Office". In other words it's often pretty crude but the social message is not to be ignored. The template for this odd little comedy exists today. Why do people still laugh at the guy getting hit in the balls on America's Home Videos? Why are people paying more for a bottle of water than a can of pop? Why do people drink Red Bull if it doesn't taste good?  We do these things because...as a whole we're not as smart as we'd like to think we are. We often depend upon advertising and image for reference. Judge is just holding a mirror up to our own simplistic media dependence and yes it's extreme and silly and broad but it's often quite hilarious. The result may not be a hit movie but cult movie sounds about right.The extras are very slim, a few deleted scenes that for the most part bring nothing new to the table.

reviewText: I somehow missed this when it came out, having dropped out of the rat race and moved to a small, hip (but unfortunately cinema-less town) for exactly the reasons that the creators of this film must have felt compelled to make it.  Yes, in realty as in the film, natural selection (besides the all too marginal Darwin Awards), largely seems to have ceased to play a role in human reproduction and the general advancement of the species; yes, it seems that exactly the wrong people, i.e. the Jerry Springer-ites, the People's Court mobs, the Fast Food Nation legions, the WWF fans, the monster truck afficionados, Scarface and gangster rap wannabes, the religious nuts, and wild eyed, gun rights obsessed country kooks, etc. etc. are indeed the ones out-reproducing the gifted, thoughtful folks who should be reproducing by at least ten to one.  The plain dumb, blind greed of recent times: the dull drift towards instant self gratification, the endemic, autonomic texting and repetitive, pointless gaming, the encroaching shallowness, incuriousity, dispassionateness, and uncultured obliviousness of so many people just idly filling their time, gratifying their medulla oblongatas, and stuffing their faces.... Idiocracy explores the implications of these dummied down  trends in broad, slightly disturbing, yet hilariously inventive and intuitive strokes.  As a recent 8 year high school teacher, I was absolutely thunderstruck by this film. The movie seemed to be welling up from my subconscious, like a lucid dream or vision, or comic nightmare, rather than from a DVD player.  It's sci-fi meets broadly and boldly stroked, inventive humor and sharp social satire. By the end, I was laughed out and purged; I felt in good company; somehow I felt bolstered, comforted, and redeemed.Luke Wilson, an average guy in the midst of the criticically dumb Bush years; a guy with no big dreams or ambition, looking for an easy ticket in an army records facility to coast through life towards a decent retirement, is "volunteered" for an army experiment to be cryogenically frozen, along with a prostitute trying to avoid jail time, and is to be awakened in one  year. When the officer in charge of the experiment is busted for pimping with his new friends (the prostitute's pimp and associates) the project is forgotten and the building is bulldozed to make a Fudruckers.  Luke wakes up in a trash avalanche 500 year later in a world that has been steadily dummied down, in which the people speak a mix of hillbilly, inner city slang, product names and guttural noises. Though some people may miss the overall satire and only see the "dumb guy" humor (like the ones being satirized)  the movie is as sophisticated as Gulliver's Travels or a wacky Clockwork Orange, using both "dumb" humor (though pehaps "innocent abroad" might be a better term) as well as scathingly dead-on and inventively hilarious satirical comedy to explore our current state and meditate, though somewhat light-heartedly, on where it all might lead us.Luke Wilson is a gem and carries the movie throughout the wild situational and character comedy with a straight faced innocence and sincerity that recalls the best of Buster Keaton.  If the masses do not know or regard him as one of our most talented comic actors, or recognize the film as a cult comic masterpiece, it is because they are as dopey and oblivious as most of the characters in the film.  Masterpiece is a risky word, but like many under-appreciated films of the past, this film, I strongly predict (if people don't get any stupider) will only grow in stature as a document from a time when things began to go seriously wrong, though the perceptiveness and comic spirit of the film is in itself cause for hope.  It might seem raunchy and rough for some of our more effete film viewers, but look around:  this film scores a rare comic and social bull's eye, however appropriate or improper one may perceive its humor.  If you consider how well and to what larger purpose the "dumb guy" humor is used (unlike the largely pointless "Hangover" or "Pineapple Express") this is as sharp and as funny a social satire as has been produced in a good many years.

reviewText: A perfectly normal man and woman get put into cryogenic storage to test how well storage works, but something goes hideously wrong and they end up sleeping for 500 years. When this Adam & Eve wake up, they discover that the world has "dumbed down" in their absence, thanks to the increased breeding of less-intelligent people and decreased breeding of more-intelligent ones. People spend their time watching television in special toilet-recliners, eating food from tubs with their hands, and visiting fast food places that specialize in prostitution. The President of the United States is an ex-porn star and wrestler; his Cabinet consists of severely limited people and one adolescent who "won a contest." reviewText: I rented this on the recommendation of a friend and end up disappointed. The plot: average G.I. Joe, Luke Wilson, is put in hibernation at the behest of military scientists and wakes up decades later to find that everyone is much dumber than they were in the year 2006. So dumb, for instance, that they don't know to water crops with water rather than the latest sports drink; and cities fall victim to landslides made of human garbage. The only person accompanying Luke Wilson on his journey is a prostitute, played by Maya Rudolph. Once in the future where our heroes don't belong, hilarity--as they say--ensues. Or should, but doesn't. I expected more, given the movie is the brain child of Mike Judge, who made one of the best word-of-mouth satires ever, Office Space. Idiocracy has some funny bits, such as the historically inaccurate museum that we see at the end, but it never really takes off. It's the kind of movie that wants it both ways: it mocks people who laugh at crotch-kick humor and then features repeated crotch-kick jokes. If a filmmaker is going to portray Americans as stupid Philistines, he should make a movie that is smart and insightful. Idiocracy is neither of those things. The characters range from one-dimensional idiots to our two dimensional heroes (Maya Rudolph's talents, in particular, are wasted). The movie is simply not on target. In many ways, popular culture is even dumber than what this movie spoofs, but at the same time, to think American culture is dumb beyond saving does an injustice to much of the good stuff out there. As far as TV goes, sure, we have to put up with stuff like Jerry Springer and Jackass. But there's also Curb Your Enthusiasm, Deadwood, and Freaks and Geeks DVDs. And you would be better off renting any of those DVDs than this one.

reviewText: Mike Judge's has given us a broad range of now classic work.  "Beavis and Butthead" were reviled generally, but adored by their audience.  "King of the Hill" is more mainstream and probably more generally loved, but the audience includes very different people.  However, the satire and bite is still there if you listen for it.His first movie, "Office Space" did not do well at the box office, but has since become a revered classic to almost everyone who has ever worked in a cubicle and will probably continue to find a new audience as young people enter the workforce and get to experience that special kind of misery for themselves."Idiocracy" is a very different creature.  It is even more rude and crude than "Beavis and Butthead", and isn't as invitingly delightful as "Office Space".  Does that mean that it is a failure?  I don't think so.  Judge manages to do the Rip van Winkle thing and send his hero into the future to make fun of his own time (as is standard for this plot device).The principle target for Judge is the dumbing down of the nation through its mass culture.  Corporations in our time cannot resist, for example, moving into the pornography business because it makes so darn much money.  In the story, they have combined sex with getting coffee, sandwiches, and much else.  Language has devolved into a base amalgam of crudities and grunts since that is all that is needed to express what passes for thought.Violence is enshrined as the principle delight of the masses and the President is a kind of big time wrestler and flipping the bird is a standard greeting.  Science in any meaningful sense is gone and the masses simply use the technologies left them.  All they can do is market the pieces still useful for business even as it imperils their very existence.  The two who are awakened in the future are the smartest people in that world.  In their world they were average at best.While some of the movie is quite funny, much of it is harsh and exasperating.  It is not a great film, but makes its points well.  Luke Wilson and Maya Rudolph are the leads and work their way through the perils of the future with some difficulties, but it turns out that what they know is so desperately needed that they find a way to rise to the top of that world without even wanting to.If you like crude social satire and didn't find "Beavis and Butthead" too terribly crude, you might enjoy this.  However, don't expect "Office Space" or even "King of the Hill".
summary: Strong Social Satire, But Harsher and Cruder Than Even Beavis and Butthead

reviewText: "Idiocracy" is the latest in a long line of stories and movies set in a future society where things have been "dumbed down" and/or the people are stupid.  As others have noted, its predecessors include the C. M. Kornbluth story "The Marching Morons" (1951) and the Woody Allen movie "Sleeper," along with "Demolition Man" and the recent TV cartoon series "Futurama."  The movie it most resembles, however, in both style and spirit, is probably "Death Race 2000," released in 1975.Like each of these works, "Idiocracy" uses its premise to satirize and comment on trends in present-day society. And to some measure, it succeeds. There are some genuinely funny moments, along with a lot of gross-out humor.  Production values are minimal, and if you're looking for a logical, coherent story, this is not the movie for you. Clearly, a society where everyone is as stupid as these people appear to be could not function at all. Who would design and build the giant vehicles used in the Rehabilitation arena, for example?I agree with the consensus rating of 3.5 stars that Amazon users have given "Idiocracy," although that figure is a bit deceptive., as it represents an average of extremes. People either think this movie is brilliant, or they think it sucks.  I disagree with both groups.  It's fairly clever in places, but hardly original in concept; see the works cited above. On the other hand, despite rumored "gutting" by Fox, it retains enough sharp-edged humor to qualify as insightful and somewhat daring.

reviewText: This is played for laughs, but the idea that people are getting dumber is actually highly plausible.  Studies have shown (or so I've been told) that domestic animals are not as bright as the wild kind.  And guess what?  We domesticate ourselves, or rather our culture does.Recently there was a story in the news about a study that showed that the brains of obese people are 16 years older than the brains of people of normal weight (these were people in their seventies).  Furthermore the brains of the obese had about eight percent less mass than the brains of people of normal weight.  Merely "fat" people had half the deficiency.  So when director Mike Judge depicts all those fat and dumb people in the future, he may be on to some serious prognosticating.As for the film itself, well, it is strangely compelling.  This future world of idiots with everything falling apart seems almost real.  It should be emphasized that all science fiction about the future is of necessity an extrapolation from the present.  In fact, the real power of futuristic tales is what they tell us about the present.  Idiocracy is no exception.  The dumbed-down, couch-potato, dimly-aware creatures shown in the film are us!  (Present company excepted of course.)Unfortunately Idiocracy is a sort of one trick pony.  The central joke wears a little thin toward the middle of the film and the concocted story collapses into the merely silly.  There are some good laughs along the way, such as crop failures due to using a kind of Gatorade on the crops called Brawndo instead of water.--Dennis Littrell, author of "The World Is Not as We Think It Is"

reviewText: Mike Judge hit comic gold with "Office Space," a satire of dilberty office workers. It became a deserving cult hit.Now he tries for a broader kind of satire -- the dumbing down of America, which nobody can deny if they've looked at test scores. "Idiocracy" is weird, crude, and a lot smarter than virtually any other movie released in the past year...The Pentagon is preparing a special hibernation project, so it can "save" its best soldiers for wartime. As a test subject, they select Joe (as in "average") Bowers (Luke Wilson), who is the absolute average of average. Along with a prostitute named Rita (Maya Rudolph) he is put into hibernation for one year.... except then the program gets shut down, and they are forgotten.Joe wakes up five hundred years in the future, only to find that mankind has changed radically. Well, maybe not so much. Turns out that welfare caused the trash hordes to reproduce a lot faster than the intellectuals. The path of evolution was thrown off. Now Rita and Joe find that they, the average, are the smartest people on the whole planet. God help them.First off, don't expect a retread of "Office Space." This is not "Office Space." It never tries to be "Office Space."This is Judge being cruder, ruder and more cynical, with jibes at welfare, blockbuster movies, dumbed-down speech, corporate logos, government, hillbillies, and corporate megastores. It's even got a TV show called "Ow, My Balls," which involves.... well, you can guess what it involves.What isn't immediately obvious is that this humor exists to satirize itself. We do have shows like "Jackass" (which would be high art in "Uh-merica"), after all. Judge is winking and double-winking all the time, as he slathers "Idiocracy" in his over-the-top, cynical art. And you know what? It's hysterically funny, and gets more so once you've seen it more than once.And it's got a pretty scary theme. "Survival of the fittest" has been overturned by the forces of stupidity? Well, I've encountered people on the same intellectual level as the Uhmericans of the future, and I find the idea terrifying. But that terror also makes you think about the dumbing-down of society... and not many satires can do that.The plot tends to meander somewhat, as Joe and Rita get acquainted with the people of the future. Fortunately the movie does stay afloat, and Rudolph and Wilson are quite funny as the "straight men" to a planet that is one big joke.The idea of a world populated by the descendents of Britney Spears is enough to make most people break out in cold sweats. And that's what "Idiocracy" does... right before it makes you laugh yourself sick.

reviewText: Enough people have been over how the release of this film was eternally delayed and, for all intents and purposes, reduced to a straight to DVD release that I won't go into all that to extensively.  Suffice to say, Mike Judge, and everyone involved here, got hosed, and Idiocracy is certainly far better than the vast majority of the crap littering the multiplexes.  It's still kinda baffling though, considering Judge's past successes with Beavis & Butthead, King of the Hill and Office Space and the money they'd already spent on it that they wouldn't even try to give it even a decent limited release, but whatever.  It's available now, anyway, and it's worth a look if you've enjoyed other Judge related material.You gotta already know the premise if you're reading this, but I'll go over it anyway:  Luke Wilson plays Joe Bowers, a thoroughly average, insignificant military librarian who is selected, along with streetwalker Rita (Maya Rudolph), to be part of an experiment in cryogenics where they're to be frozen for a year.  Various administrative problems come up, however, and the project is forgotten entirely, so that Joe and Rita don't awaken until 2505.  Things are not well, however, as over the past 500 years dullards and trailer trash have continued to breed wildly while the intelligent held back, carefully waiting for just the right moment.  They waited too long and bred too little, so now the world is completely overrun with morons, so much so that Joe and Rita are now apparently the two most intelligent people in the world.  Joe sees only one solution, albeit a rather improbable one:  He needs find a time machine and get the hell out of there.  And so we're off.As you've no doubt heard or guessed, Idiocracy is a rather vicious and blunt satire of modern culture.  As other reviewers have pointed out, though it may take this long for intelligence to be thoroughly bred out of human society, it sure wouldn't take 500 years for American culture to degenerate this far.  Examples:  Speech has been reduced to a barely coherent, ultra-profane mishmash of urban and rural slang; product placement and corporate sponsorship are now omnipresent, so much so that now cabinet members spout on about how such and such a thing is "brought to you by Carl's Jr."; the most popular show on TV is, apparently, "Ow! My Balls!" on the Violence network, and news shows are now hosted by bronzed, shirtless pro-wrestler types.  Furthermore, society is on the verge of disaster, as the current populace is just too stupid to deal with issues of pollution, agriculture etc. And so on.  This all points to the main flaw in the film: it's pretty one note, and the story as such exists pretty much just to propel us from one satiric scenario to the next.  Fundamentally, there isn't anything overwhelming sophisticated about the satire; they just take anything that currently exists and increase the crudity, violence and sexuality in it 1000 fold.  Still, Judge and co-writer Etan Cohen are clearly smart guys, and they're able to inject genuine cleverness into the sometimes obvious subject matter.  I'd go into greater specifics, but explaining a joke never really works and tends to ruin it when you do hear it, so you'll just have to take a chance.There isn't too much to be said about the technical aspects of the film.  If you like the humor and ideas you'll like it, if not you won't.  This is a pretty low-rent future, so it's rarely convincing, but, of course, this sorta heavy satire isn't meant to be accepted on a realistic or dramatic level.  Besides, having a frequently cheesy, unbelievable looking world is pretty appropriate from a thematic standpoint, I think.  There isn't too much to say about the performances either, as most of the characters are borderline-retarded at best, so overwhelmingly broad, simple performance are par the course.  Luke Wilson plays his typical dull-witted, average guy role.  He's appealing enough as such, though if you never liked him doing this before this film won't likely convert you.  Maya Rudolph is co-lead, and she doesn't really have all that much to do since she mostly just plays straight man to all the wackiness around her, but she does that adequately enough, I suppose.  Of the supporting roles, Terry Crews is probably most notable as the heavily be-muscled, pro-wrestler/porn star/president of the USA.  There's not much to say about him apart from that he was funny. I laughed. Hahahaha you see.As this is a very one-dimensional film it's a good thing that it's a scant 78 minutes, not including the credits.  Even at such a length it feels a bit too long, largely because the few attempts at outright drama that they include don't really work, and these things predominate at the end.  Still, the good easily outweighs the bad, and it doesn't stay around too long after wearing out it's welcome.Well, that's all I've got.  Once again, Judge fans will probably like it, I dunno about anyone else.  Some will tell you that this could've been so much more, and maybe they're right, but it's got enough to recommend it now.Grade: B

reviewText: Okay, I admit it. I enjoy a good fart joke now and then. But when that fart joke is 90 minutes long and wins 8 Academy Awards, including one for Best Screenplay, then I'd say we are in trouble. Many of this film's reviewers think that Idiocracy itself is a 90 minute long fart joke, but then, they probably missed the point of director Mike Judge's classic Beavis and Butthead too. In other words, while much of the humor is indeed base, it is the audience itself that is the butt (pun intended) of the joke.All the reviews I've seen of this film take its premise of a moronic future literally. The lawyer of the future sits in his recliner cum toilet, stuffing his face with artificial food-goop whilst ogling the Violence Channel, and it doesn't take a great leap of the imagination for me to see in this Joe Sixpack's vision of utopia. reviewText: I made the mistake of telling my boss, when I was only a third of the way through this movie, what a smart satire it was of modernity. The poor guy went out and bought a copy and, unlike me, watched it all the way through. When I saw him next, he wanted to know what I thought was so funny. Though "Idiocracy" has many moments of clarity and brilliance, had I watched farther than I did, I would have understood his point."Idiocracy" tells the tales of Joe Bauers, played by the ever-amiable Luke Wilson -- a low ranking Air Force drudge who is more than happy to hang onto his out-of-the-way cellar desk job. Destiny intervenes in the shape of a test project to freeze ordinary humans, and next thing you know Bauers (and a hooker from downtown) end up in suspended animation for 500 years. Meanwhile, Earth's idiots have outbred the smarties and (by dint of natural selection) now run the planet. Ordinary-IQ Bauers wakes up and is suddenly, by default, the smartest man on Earth.The sight gags are pretty funny. Garbage is piled as high as skyscrapers. An actual restaurant chain with an already near-scatalogical name (rhymes with "crud muckers") undergoes two additional name changes to something hilariously uncouth and unprintable. Hospitals are staffed by gum-chewing idiots who painstakingly diagnose a patient's complaints using a pictorial shape board. You need to freeze this shot to appreciate the humor packed into this device alone. Language has devolved to a combination of hillbilly, valley-speak and grunts. Corporate logos are ubiquitous, and everything -- down to the clothing worn by the proles, even the judge and lawyers at court -- sports a bevy of corporate brands like NASCAR race cars. Bauers' "intelligence" marks him as a threat, and he is widely feared by the idiot citizenry. He runs into trouble, but ends up as advisor to the President, a foul-mouthed, black former wrestler and porn star.My boss's opinion notwithstanding, "Idiocracy" is brilliant and incisive, especially early on. But around the halfway mark, it gets a little too serious and the gags and insights peter out. It's here alas, that the film's magic runs out and one begins to wonder how this gaggle of morons manages to maintain the machines and computers they depend on. Add a romance and a silly chase scene, and the fun is over. But while it lasted it was a great ride. Kudos to Mike Judge for daring to name the direction of our society -- which has quickly become a celebration of the lowbrow, the irrelevant and the vulgar.My boss? I offered to buy the film from him for the $5 it cost him to buy a used copy. But he insisted that it wasn't even worth that much, and he slid it across the desk into my hands. I still don't think it's a bad film, though surely not the masterpiece that some believe it is. Cult film? Not likely. But "Idiocracy's" successes and its great ideas make it worth a watch.

reviewText: We have a local radio DJ here with a weekly sketch called "Curb Your Intelligence." He interviews men and women on the street on questions such as, whether Barack Obama is a threat to the United States. Or he'll ask, "What does the Department of Labor do?" One woman replied, "They landscape, they do your lawn. Plant bushes, trees."Most people can name the judges on American Idol, three NFL teams, the star of Forrest Gump, three fast-food restaurants, or the star of Snakes on a Plane, but they don't know Maryland's two senators, or the three branches of government (one man, with a questioning inflection, guessed, "Democrats, Republicans and liberals?").What does the "I" in "CIA" stand for? Folks guessed Investigations, "I don't know," Information ...Real stupidity is hilarious, and unexpected. Dumb people can be an unintended delight as they refilter the world around them. (Take my neighborhood, where one woman asked if my dog, a sheltie, was a "borderline collie.")The problems with Mike Judge's Idiocracy, about the dumbing down of the United States in 500 years, are several:* Stupid people are portrayed as dull and slow, rather than what they really are: funny in ways you could never anticipate.* This movie could have been set, rather than 500 years in the future, 20 years in the past. Allan Bloom's "The Closing of the American Mind" came out in 1987. Fuddruckers burger joints were founded in 1980, with a name already several miles down the road toward the even ruder variant that appears in "Idiocracy." "Jackass the Movie" is more recent, 2002, and it certainly wouldn't take 500 more years to devolve into a show such as "Idiocracy" depicts, called "Ow! My Balls." Five months is more like it. Product placement, cross-positioning and sponsorships are only slightly more blatant in 2505 than than already are today.* Judge's brilliant premise and film title, that dumb people outbreed smart people, is hamstrung by  a weak script, with cliched struggles in the future, and a bit of cheap look to some of the sets. if you have a Mad Max style amphitheater battle, for Private Bowers' "Monday night rehabilitation," it better not look like it cost $1.50 to stage.More humor about what's it's like to be bright in a stupid world would have enriched the script. Pvt. Bowers and Rita don't seem to be as annoyed or crafty as they might have been given their phenomenal intellectually superiority over the dummies of the future.Jokes are executed miserably. For example, a dumb, mumbling john can't get a prostitute. The portrayal of this john just looks like lousy acting. We also see more than enough borderline bigotry, as garishly dressed blacks and Hispanics are portrayed as WWF style characters in the presidency and Cabinet. I would cringe at the thought of watching "Idiocracy" with black friends.That said, "Idiocracy" may be widely remembered more for the potential movie it could have been, than for what it is. The opening sequence on breeding is fairly clever. Two high-IQ yuppies postpone children, while trailer trash breed like rabbits. Too true. If only the script hadn't fallen off the shelf after this opening.

reviewText: Mike Judge's Idiocracy is a silly but brilliant social satire which was crushed by the studio system.  For reasons unknown (or unconfirmed), no promotional materials other than posters were released, no previews were held for critics, and the movie was only ever released theatrically in seven cities.  Don't let this lack of studio support prevent you from picking up this great title on DVD, however.Idiocracy is set in a futuristic world in which unintelligent people have out-bred the intelligent ones.  Army librarian Joe Bauers (Luke Wilson) was part of a hibernation experiment in 2005 that accidentally lasted 500 years, to the modern age of Idiocracy, and he awakes in a world in which is brand of average common sense is regarded as "tardation."  Bauers lacks the required barcode tattoo of every citizen and has an unusual amount of common sense and ability to question the status quo.  He's jailed and accused of crimes, but has the knowledge to save the planet (by watering crops with water instead of sports drinks, and so on).The genius of Idiocracy is its criticism of modern consumer culture, of branding, of Costo-like warehouses, fast food, and our addiction to Starbucks.  If this had gotten a wider release, many of the catch phrases would pervade pop culture, like those from Office Space have done.  Did the studio crush this movie for fear of a corporate backlash from the American brands parodied?  Maybe.  Do yourself a favor and pick it up on DVD.
summary: An off-beat comedy and social satire plagued by release problems

reviewText: Ha... It's always this way with these comedic gems that become cult classics.  The Big Lebowski made 17 million at the box office, Office Space 10.  Why?  It was way over the head the general audience, that didn't catch the subtleties, nuances and details of good comedy.  Confusion.  Others literally had to explain to them why it was funny, why it was good.  Then a DVD comes out.  Then everyone's a fan, and has been since day 1.  Then the same people that didn't get it are the same ones repeatedly [and bumblingly] quoting the movie until you just want to slap them.And so, I am honored to be the first one to stand up and say Idiocracy is absolute, pure genius!  The satire is brilliant and biting, the comedy blunt on the surface (yet oh so relevant) and perfectly delivered by skilled actors.  It's rated 3 now ("stupid funny"?... wrong).  But mark this review, someday Idiocracy will be rated 4.5 with hundreds of glowing reviews (see above).Idiocracy is about excess; total instant gratification, consumerism, crudity and ... decline on an grand scale: hand jobs with latte, slot machines at the hospital, tissue style dispensers of advertisement slathered "Pro Wear", CostCos the size of cities, 5 time Smackdown champion President, and so on.Idiocracy is about erosion.  The slide and decline of all the things that make (made?) humanity great.  Morality, hard work, standards, art, civility, creativity...  everything.  It's about shutting off your brain and doing what feels good and ignoring art for the sake of "entertainment".  It's about being wasteful, rude, lazy, stupid, crass... and being obliviously happy out it!The details, details, details contained within Idiocracy!  I love sci-fi and Mike Judge's Idiocracy is without a doubt the funniest sci-fi ever.  There are so many details of this terrible future in the movie; you would have to watch it a dozen times to catch all of the clever stabs.  I could edit this review for years adding new observations.  I won't, but do yourself a favor and enjoy searching for and scrutinizing them.The advertising in Idiocracy is hilarious.  It is everywhere.  Everywhere.  To me, it's not so much a critique about the ethics of advertising and marketing as it is an attack that they work so well on so many!  Why is it so damn ubiquitously pervasive and increasingly insistent and invasive?  Because some one out there is falling for it...  "Welcome to COSTCO...  I love you."  This is why greeters are there!  Yet it obviously is making some of us think that these corporations actually do care. Proclaiming love seems a logical end result. Idiocracy is about a populace totally enslaved by marketing. "It's got electrolytes!"Some are branding Idiocracy as an anti-capitalistic diatribe against "red state" culture and using it elevate themselves in all their smug, elitist glory.  While Idiocracy is a hilarious critique of monolithic corporations, to claim that is its thesis is both false and missing the point.  It's so much more... I've been to Whole Foods in San Fran and Seattle <shudder> and there were more shiny Subarus and ipods than I could fathom.  Talk about conformity and consumerism.  Except "blue state" consumerism uses earth tones and usually floats a higher price tag leading to increased corporate profit margins (which is willingly traded in exchange for a little self satisfaction).  Very few (if any) in this country are immune.Idioracy wasn't just poorly promoted (neglected even), it was downright suppressed. "FOX News; Violence Channel correspondent. . ." HAHA!  Idiocracy is subversive.  As hell.  It is a disrespect of the highest order to all the lowbrow geniuses (who are the peddlers), in charge of FOX Networks.  Cheers to Mike Judge, who didn't compromise his art or his integrity when dealing with these morons who wanted this masterpiece to die.Trust me people, Idiocracy has a lot to offer.  It's not as human (or accessible) as Office Space. But in my opinion it's even funnier!  Cult Classic by 2009.

reviewText: Sure, it's no Office Space.  But then again, how can you expect another one like that?  Judge's little-known "Idiocracy" is something of an enigma: short (85 min) and to the point, but after watching it, you're left feeling you might've missed something, as if Judge must've had some hidden message in mind. From there, it's an all-out critique on dumbed-down society and over the top marketing.  The greatness of the movie is not in its complex message or theme, but rather in how closely the future mirrors the present state of America.  The number one show in the future ("Ow My Balls!") is a parody of some of the dumber shows popular today (e.g. "Jackass"), and the marketing of some products ("The Thirst Mutilator" and such) poke fun at some of the "extreme" products out today, or those with a bunch of ingrediants that few even know what they do ("it's got electrolytes!"). And the Starbucks and Walmarts of the future get the worst of it.So all in all, a great comedy with an interesting premise.  I was going to give it 4 stars, but after researching the movie to discover why I'd never heard of it in the theaters, I gave it a bonus star.  Seems Fox found the movie too edgy / insulting to people (and sponsers!), so they did absolutely no promoting of the movie and released it in only around 10 movies in the whole US - the reason the first time you may come across this is in a Blockbuster.  Give it a shot, it's worth the 85 minutes.

reviewText: My husband and I watched Idiocracy for a second time last weekend.  Overall, the film is okay.  There are places where I laughed out loud.  It is a "funny-stupid" film.  Not a great epic, but not complete trash either.  A good choice for an evening when you need to give your brain a rest.However, this is also a "smart, funny-stupid" move. Stereotypical "dumb" people will multiply faster than love-struck bunnies; the movers, thinkers, and doers will continue to put children off so long that they will not be able to have them.  America's number one show will be "Ow, My Balls" (and if you've every seen Jerry Springer, Big Brother, The Real Life, Fear Factor, Jackass, etc., you KNOW Ow, My Balls is next); language will continue to deteriorate until it is some kind of street-valley-funk-hiphop conglomeration; technology and the very ability to make or repair anything will disappear; the president of the United States will be pro-wrestler; garbage will be piled so high that landslides threaten major cities; and corporations and advertising will rule the world. At that time he was advocating the removal of the word "antelope" from all textbooks, to be replaced with the word "deer".  He felt that word antelope was too hard for America's children and that it was a somewhat useless word, since there were no antelope on this continent.  Which I believe would come as somewhat of a shock to the millions of Americans who live "where the deer and the ANTELOPE play!"This movie will make you think.  Which is what a movie should do.

reviewText: Idiocracy, meaning rule of the stupid, is a dystopian film from Director Mike Judge (Office Space) that cost about $30 million to make but only made about half a million dollars because the film's distributor wanted nothing to do with promoting the film.  There were no advertisements, no trailers, and the film was eventually released on just 130 screens in a limited amount of American cities.  The film is written by successful veterans, stars some solid talent, and the CGI effects and art direction were likely not inexpensive.  Unlike most films that a distributor ignores, Idiocracy was well-received by critics and I will echo here that it is indeed a very good satire.  The distributor was of course Fox and they were likely embarrassed to release a film that does what any good dystopian tale does, and that is strongly denounce the self-destructive culture we currently live in and continue to facilitate.Joe Bauers (Luke Wilson) is the military's most average soldier.  He is literally tested to be of average intelligence, health, etc.  Rita (Maya Rudolph) is a prostitute who is seemingly always fearful of her pimp Upgraydd.  They are both selected as guinea pigs for a classified program that aims to place them in hibernation for one year.  They are put into coffin-like chambers and forgotten about after the program dissolves.  They are left there for 500 years until they awaken after their chambers are forced open by the great garbage avalanche of 2505.  The setting they exist in is a low-intelligence society influenced by dysgenics, cultural and moral devolution, and powerful corporate influence and consumerism.  Starbucks and Costco have basically become brothels.  Crops are fed with Gatorade because of, you know, the electrolytes.  Doctors diagnose people as "tarded".  The president is an alpha-male nationalist and former professional wrestler/porn star. A museum shows that Charlie Chaplin was leader of the Nazi party who fought using dinosaurs in their army but was eventually "Un-Nazied" by the "Un" (the United Nations).  There are some more vulgar and hilarious ways in which corporations evolve to satisfy the ever decreasing intelligence of our society that I'd like to mention but can't.  Finally, average soldier Joe Bauer is tested to be the most intelligent human being on Earth in 2505 and the rest of the story centers on his development in this environment.  There are also some really interesting supporting roles from Thomas Haden Church and Justin Long, among others.There are a few production flaws and at times some clunky dialogue, but really those are just nitpickings.  Idiocracy is at times absolutely hilarious and it manages to make its point throughout.  I think with many dystopian films people get offended by the societal criticism.  However, I was encouraged by the truth within the satire here and enjoyed the film tremendously.  If you find yourself angry just reading the movie summary in this review then I wouldn't necessarily recommend watching Idiocracy.
summary: Hilarious Dystopian Satire Muted by Distributor

reviewText: The mastermind of "King of the Hill" and "Beavis and Butthead," Mike Judge, gives all of us a loud, buffoonish warning of things to come in "Idiocracy."  It's the tale of an average joe/military librarian named Joe (Luke Wilson)who, along with a prostitute named Rita (Maya Rudolph), takes part in a hibernation experiment for the military.  Instead of awaking one year later, however, they wake up five hundred years in the future.  The really bad thing is that thanks to the commercialization of society and the fact that smart people don't breed as fast as those who are less than perfect, the future that Joe and Rita wake up in is terribly......well, dumb.  The film explores how a life dependent on the media and heavy promotion reduces the average person into an electrolyte drinking, TV watching, lazy fool.When he registers the highest score ever on an aptitude test, Joe is thrust into the political arena by President Camacho (Terry Crews).  Camacho hopes that with Joe's brainpower, he can regain his popularity as president of the United States.  Crops have dried up and people are beginning to starve.  The future is very, very bleak, and all thanks to the boobtube and those talking heads on the five o'clock news.Overall, the story is just too boring to really send the point of the film home.  Wilson is game in all of his averageness, but he really doesn't have much to work with.  Maya Rudolph does everything she can with Rita, and gives one of the better performances in the show.  Justin Long, Thomas Haden Church, and an uncredited Sara Rue give the best performances in the film overall, even if they only get a few seconds of screen time.I agree with Judge that the world is headed for an idiocracy, but he misfired with this film.  It's not intelligently funny or even idiotically funny.  In fact, it mirrors the world Judge says will eventually be our downfall.  It's loud, annoying and silly without being all that fun to watch.  Heck, it even has Dax Shepard in it, who along with Ashton Kutcher, has done his part to contribute to the downfall of mankind via "Punk'd."I was let down by this movie.  It has a very good message to it, but it isn't presented in a form that's as smart or funny as many hoped it would be.  I only mildly recommend this movie, but I wouldn't go so far as to tell someone to purchase it.

As with much satirical commentary on society, the idiocy of the movie (excuse the pun) contains a kernel of truth that will (hopefully) make you think.I do agree with the some of the lower reviewers that the movie was a bit overdone, and that the point could have been better made if it hadn't focused so much on stupid-funny. reviewText: The funniest thing about this film is the concept: Darwin's theory of survival of the fittest is no longer applicable to a species that has no more natural predators.  As a result, it is now survival of the most reproductive.  Since smart people wait and debate before they mate, and since stupid people (according to this film) have as much sex and babies as jack rabbits, well, the future of the world ain't lookin' so good.  Er, isn't.  Isn't looking so good.Average Joe (Luke Wilson) is put in a top secret hibernation experiment that goes awry; he wakes up 500 years later (instead of one) to find that America is now ruled and populated by morons.  In fact, tests reveal that he is currently the smartest person alive.  He is accompanied by fellow hibernator Rita (an underplayed, oddly restrained Maya Rudolph) and a dumb-as-driftwood Frito (Dax Shepard).I didn't laugh at all when I watched "Idiocracy," but I did smile, and I did find parts of it funny (the poorly planned sign for the Saint God hospital; buildings lashed together; the cameos by Stephen Root and Justin Long).  I suppose I knew, even after the spot-on opening sequence, that I wasn't in for much.  After all, the premise milks itself dry in a matter of minutes.  There is only so much you can do when 99% of your characters are, literally, complete morons.Luke tries his best with his straight-man role (an identity he assumes well), but he is surrounded by actors and actresses who aren't being asked to exercise their chops.  After all, playing dumb is pretty easy.  The script doesn't call for much insight (or hope), either; Mike Judge doesn't really have a message so much as he has a warning, and it's not a warning even he's taking all that seriously.  He doesn't need to, after all.  It doesn't take 90 seconds, let alone 90 minutes to get his point.That point having been made in the first fifteen minutes, "Idiocracy" spends the rest of its time trying to get some mileage out of jokes that are, necessarily, stupid.  Most of what's really funny in this flick are the half-second pause-or-you'll-miss-em visual gags, like road signs, various places of business, or characters in the background.  The special effects budget for the film wasn't very hefty, but they've made do as well as they need to, and, again, some grins are to be had at the new "style" of architecture, and the fact that (surprise, surprise) everything from sex to prison guards is affixed with corporate logos.It's all marginally witty stuff, but also incredibly silly, and in that sense, the movie both succeeds and fails.  It's a one-note gag stretched out into an entire musical.  I think it's just too bad that Judge didn't feel like putting more brains into the film.  As it is, for a movie that's so quick to convict idiocy, it sure does cater to it a lot, too.

reviewText: The way Fox handled this film is destined to become the stuff of legends, and itself should be sufficient reason to see it. Its release was delayed for years, the effects budget was cut drastically, it was never screened for critics and when it WAS released, it opened in a grand total of 130 theaters nationwide, and yanked very quickly after that.There's enough discussion of the plot here, so I'll skip that. It owes an obvious debt to Kornbluth's "The Marching Morons", and that, too, is enough reason to see it. It is definitely one of the most bitter, cynical, and bleak movies I can recall viewing, and it has far more depth than a superficial look would convey. (I found myself hitting the "pause" button frequently - there's a LOT of details to check out.) The anti-corporate slams are fast and furious, and the scene of people playing the slots hoping for medical care is priceless. Those who complain that "it's dumb" obviously just don't get the point. (Maybe it's too much Fox News?)Unfortunately, it loses energy in the second half with the contrived "romance". And in spite of what the case says, it is full-screen only. (The case claims it's widescreen, and double-sided.)  It could have used some better effects and post-production work, but the studio wouldn't have it. A commentary would have really been welcome, too. What we have, then, is a flawed masterpiece, certainly a future cult film, and maybe, just maybe, one day Mike Judge will get to "finish" it *his* way. I know I'll be hoping.
summary: Too hot for Fox to handle - grab it before it disappears forever

None of the other reviewers mentioned this one major point of the movie, and admittedly it is a touchy one; Judge depicts stupid people accurately when it comes to their overriding interest in sex---making babies is the one thing stupid people are VERY good at. The old joke goes like this... Q: what do rich people do instead of having sex? A: rule the world. In "Idiocracy", Judge has turned the old joke around 180 degrees.Experience, as always, is the best teacher, and "Idiocracy" unflatteringly depicts the sort of rabid homophobia and coeval anti-intellectualism which were present in our public high schools during the early '80s, when the "proud to be stupid" movement was in its infancy. I'm not kidding; after 20 years, it seems almost as if there has been a successful if subtle real-life campaign to de-stigmatize stupidity. Nowadays, a deliberate slur against someone's intelligence will more often than not result in the slur being taken as a compliment rather than an insult. Frankly, I wonder why lobotomies haven't surpassed nose jobs and boob jobs as our elective surgeries of choice---"you, too, can enjoy instant idiocy!"As for the reviewers who didn't find this film funny, or for whom it hit a little too close to home, these people are obviously of the same sort "Idiocracy" is lampooning.An enjoyable film, though dark, for those of us who happen to be intelligent.

reviewText: Many people didn't like this movie because they expected a satire that would allow them to comfortably laugh at "the other".  Like we laughed at Ted Knight in Caddyshack or at Bill Lumburg in Office Space, or at all the pepole on the Jerry Springer show.  But this film makes you feel uneasy, precisely because it brilliantly forces you to recognize how YOU are part of the problem.  So you aren't going to find it funny if you can't laugh at yourself.It's supposed to be about sort of reverse eugenics, with the dumb pepole outbreeding the smart people, so much of the audience came in thinking of themselves as the latter and looking forward to making fun of the Jerry Springer set.  Marketing and the deterioration of our popular culture are what this film is really about though.I'll cite just one example.  At one point Frito and the gang are fleeing from the police, when their car is disabled by remote control and stops.  Before they get half a block the police have zeroed in on the car and start spraying it methodically with gunfire.  Pedestrians passing by slow down to observe the automatic weapon-fire, and begin to get excited.  Irrationally, Frito pauses as well, and starts to backtrack.  The crowd begins to leap up and down and push and shove each other.  Frito is drooling in excitement over the destruction of his own car, as his friends pull him away...The disturbing thing is, I was drawn into the car being shot up as well, as an audience member.  The gunfire was pretty realistic and the destruction spectacular.  I like guns.  I found myself being mesmerized by the spectacle myself for a moment.  I laughed.  Then I frowned.  Then I laughed again, harder.  This movie forces us to recognize how easily we are manipulated, and how we are being dumbed down.  Thats not always a happy feeling.And thats what makes this film so brilliant.

reviewText: Comparing Mike Judge's "Idiocracy" with Alfonso Cuaron's "Children of Men" in some ways is like comparing "The Killing Fields" with "Dumb and Dumber." Yet, underneath all the silly sex and potty humor, Judge's vision of the future is as despairing as Cuaron's. Whereas "Children of Men" postulates a future endangered by the lack of fertility, "Idiocracy" presents a dystopia created by a surfeit of fertility. In a world where humankind has no natural predators, the deliberately pompous narrator tells us, survival belongs not to the fittest, but to those who reproduce the most. Therefore, Judge--the creator of Beavis and Butt-head--presents the year 2505 as a time in which Beavises and Butt-heads crowd the streets, perform surgery, adjudicate the courts, run major corporations and occupy the White House. Into this world Judge thrusts Joe (Luke Wilson) and Rita (Maya Rudolph), two painfully average victims of a 2005 suspended animation experiment gone awry, who find themselves by far the smartest people in the world. The frightened, angry populace gives them a choice: find solutions to the skyscraper-sized mounds of garbage and dust-bowl farming conditions that afflict the society, or else face "Monday Night Rehabilitation," which is much better seen than described. "Idiocracy" is far from a refined cinematic experience, and it's also far from perfect (Judge should have ditched the obtrusive narration after the prologue). But Judge's basic vision--of a bread-and-circuses society choked by rampant consumerism, too lazy and dull-witted to solve its own problems or notice the Orwellian intrusion of government into private lives--is uncomfortably pertinent to our own situation. Furthermore, the movie is zesty and fun, with Judge and his cast taking obvious glee in enacting a world filled with morons. Just try to pay attention when, every so often, they hold up a mirror.

reviewText: Ok, so I'm a big fan of dystopian books, so when I heard about this movie I knew I had to see it.  The very premise was something I could laugh about as I've seen it happen in practice.We are introduced to the world while they explore population growth.  Most noticeably is the fact that less intelligent people are procreating far greater than those with higher IQ's.  The family tree keeps piling up squashing the scientists, doctors, and others until we fear for the future.  Then we are introduced to Joe.  Joe Bauers (Luke Wilson) is an average guy about to be used for a scientific experiment.  He and Rita (Maya Rudolph), a woman donated by her pimp are going to be put in a freeze and supposedly only a year will go by before they are awakened.  Something goes horribly awry however.Joe awakens to the year 2505 and right away knows something is wrong.  At first he's not sure what year it is but stumbles around through people watching whole movies just showing someone's hind end, wearing enough advertisements on their clothing to blind someone, and not being able to understand him due to his "pretentious" way of speaking.  When he doesn't have the means to pay his hospital bill he's quickly shipped off to prison where after a IQ test and a tattoo being created on his arm, he daringly escapes.  With the help of his lawyer Frito (Dax Shepard) he sets off to find Rita and a time machine and get out, but before he can, he is recaptured and sent to work for the President as he is the smartest man in the world.  For him to escape, he has to solve the world's problems.They did an ok job at casting the characters.  While they all did their best with a very strange dialogue and script, some of it felt stilted.  Dax Shepard as Frito was good, but at times his character was actually boring, despite its idiocy.  Luke Wilson as the one sane voice was strange just because I'm so accostomed to him playing roles where his character is a little slow.  I did like Rita.  She was sassy and played the role quite well.Since this is a dystopian future where everyone is an idiot there is a lot of terrible humour in the movie.  Fart jokes abound and sex is a very big theme.  This would be pretty funny usually except that this same "joke" is constantly repeated throughout the entire film. It got to be that some of the jokes were boring at times. It would have been nice for them to add some other elements relating to the stupidity within the film as well, such as how people are caring for children without killing them off or how the big factories are running with such a low grade of personnel.  They did throw in how big companies had taken over but I didn't understand that somehow as its difficult to run a big company and I just didn't see these people managing to maintain such an enterprise.The total plot was well done but the pacing of the film wasn't the greatest.  They spent too much time on certain areas of the film and I could find myself getting tired of some of the scenes. They did do a good job of getting the message across though and these elements of stupidity becoming prevalent were high priority in the film.Overall I did like the movie and found it tremendously funny.  I just wish they had taken it a little further.Review by M. Reynard 2010

reviewText: Office Space helmer and creator of Beavis & Butt-Head and King of the Hill Mike Judge crafted this clever, funny, and deadpan satire that sadly went unnoticed by audiences, thanks in no part to Fox.  Idiocracy stars Luke Wilson as Joe Bauers, an army private who is the definition of "average" in terms of intelligence and nearly everything else.  He is picked, along with a prostitute named Rita (Saturday Night Live vet Maya Rudolph) for a top secret hibernation experiment where they will be asleep for a year.  Instead, the experiment becomes forgotten about, and both wake up 500 years in the future where the world has become overpopulated, overpolluted, and above all, incredibly stupid.  While Judge's satire on American society and culture is far from subtle, Idiocracy's message is what really makes it worthwhile.  This message, laced within visual gags and some truly hilarious moments, is one that should not be missed, and Idiocracy is a film that should not be missed either, even if Fox went out of their way to not promote the film.  The rest of the cast, which includes Dax Shepard, Terry Crews (as the president no less), and Office Space's David Herman, are incredibly fitting as well in their roles.  All in all, Idiocracy may have benefited from being a little more subtle, but it is a wonderful satire that deserves your attention regardless.
summary: A wonderful satire that should be seen

Joe Bowers who is quite literally an average Joe.  For this reason, the army selects him to be frozen in time as part of an experiment.  It goes awry when he awakes 500 years in the future as opposed to one year.  He finds a future where it seems only the stupid people are producing offspring, where commercial culture has found its way into everything from education to the naming of children and people drink a gatorade like sports drink instead of water.  For this reason, Joe is now the smartest man in the world and might hold the key to this society's future.Judge's satire succeeds because it is unrelenting and unapologetic.  It's amazing that some of the products named in this movie didn't sue, as Judge shows a city sized Costco where you can get a law degree or a Carls, Jr. whose future slogan is a profane spin on "Don't Bother Me, I'm Eating."  The plot involves the people of the future looking to Joe for guidance to save their world.  The story is kind of sloppy, but that's okay.  Much like Judge's own Office Space, it merely serves as a backdrop for Judge's satire to play out.  It's the films keen observations on where were headed that make this film so funny and rightly timed.Perhaps we'll never understand why this DVD will be the first opportunity for many to see this funny film.  Maybe it's satire is a little too unrelenting.  Looking at many of the movies that come out and rise to number one, Judge may be right about where we're headed. reviewText: Mike Judge has created some great comedic work in the past, especially his previous film Office Space, and his television series, King of the Hill.  With that track record I had high hopes for the film.  Judge takes the basic concept from the Woody Allen film, Sleeper.  However, his vision of the nightmare future shows us a nation plagued by laziness, selfishness, and completely immersed in commercialism.Is it exaggerated?  Yes.  Is it over the top?  Yes.  Is it funny?  Yes it is.  The interesting thing is that this film can work on two levels.  On the surface the movie is dumb.  It wants you to laugh at stupid people doing stupid things.  Some will find the concept of a show where a man gets hit in the crotch every five seconds just as hilarious as the denizens of this demented future do.  Others will find such a concept juvenile.The real comedy of the film comes when you dig a bit deeper.  I think Judge is pointing at this possible future and asking us to look at our present.  Why does everything need a sponsor?  When did thinking become annoying?  Just because it's easy, does it make it better?  Pretty weighty questions from the guy who brought us Beevis and Butthead.  Like I said, most of that is buried in the film.  The surface is much more stupid.  You can enjoy the film either way.Judge assembled a solid cast.  Luke Wilson plays Joe like a regular guy lost in a moronic world (haven't we all had that experience at one time or another in our lives).  Maya Rudolph as Rita also does a good job as a working girl just trying to survive in this stupid state society.  Dax Shepard plays the ultra-dense Frito with gusto.  The rest of the supporting cast does a good job with the roles and making you laugh and pray to God that this is not our unfortunate future.The script is a great mixture of obvious and stupid jokes, with pointed and sharp satire.  Somethings get a little too obvious at points, but for the most part the lines are funny and the situation (while a little generic at times) is entertaining.My only complaints about the movie are some of the weaker effects work (doesn't look like Fox helped out Mike Judge with an appropriate budget) and some lack of subtly.The disc itself has a clear picture, good sound but weak extras.  A few deleted scenes is all we get.  I would have loved to hear Mike Judge commentary.  I've heard that the movie has a sordid history.  I'm sure Fox didn't want Judge spilling the beans on that aspect of the film.  Oh well.I think Idiocracy is a cult classic in the making.  It's funny, disturbing, and has some great moments in it.  Mike Judge continues his winning streak in my book.  I hope enough people see this film and tell their friends about it.  It can serve as a warning to others.  Don't be stupid: think for yourself.
summary: A surprisingly smart movie about stupidity gone stupidly wrong
