reviewText: I didn't even know this movie existed up until 2 weeks ago. I never read or heard anything on it. The movie has warped into a Cult Classic for me, after watching it for the first time. So far I have had the movie on my DVR for over 2 weeks now, and I have only deleted it now because I bought the DVD. Normally I watch a movie once and then I'm good for years, but not Idiocracy. I have now seen this movie 10 times! To think I almost didn't watch it. I had confused Luke Wilson, with Owen Wilson. Owen is great at doing comedies, but this movie needs a Straight-Lace personality to pull it off and Luke does that perfectly.(Basic Plot)Luke Wilson, AKA Joe Bauers, is an average man in every possible way. Basic IQ, basic health, just basic; which makes him perfect for an experiment in Cryogenics. The Army also finds Maya Rudolph, AKA Rita to participate. As long as her pimp gets paid. This "Getting His Money" theme plays throughout the movie (I will get to this later). The experiment goes horribly wrong and they are both forgotten about for 500 years. They are awakened in a time where the Status Quo has dropped to the point where humans are on the verge of starvation. It seems that more idiots have spawned children then intelligent people, creating an inbred Society of morons. Which in reality is a true concept; as mean as that sounds. So this general idea adds a type of realism to the movie. Human Speech is no longer what we would consider formal. It is a mix of Ebonics, Valley Girl, ect. Much in the way that our ancestors would view how we pronounce words today, as being crude; the Idiocracy future is even worse. Joe Bauers is able to understand them, but they view him as being a "Fag." This Broken-English is already on it's way to becoming the norm, so I love the idea that Mike Judge added this to his movie. What makes the movie so funny is the little details. When Joe first meets up with Dax Shepard, AKA Frito, Dax is watching a show called "Ow! My Balls!" on a Giant-Screen TV. But the only part of the screen where you can view the show is in the very middle. The rest of the surrounding screen is full of flashing, blinking advertisements. These annoying banners, which cover up 80% of the screen, are the predictable future to a practice that didn't exist back in the 90's, but are now EVERYWHERE in our own time! So in Idiocracy future, your 7 Foot TV screen, will really only end up being 20 Inches after Advertisers fill the rest of the space with banners.Water is no longer consumed; instead it is now a Gatorade-Type drink called Brawndo that is the most consumed beverage. This again comes from present culture where a person would rather drink sugar-water then just plain-old water. Waves and claps of respect have been replaced with the Middle Finger. Swear words are also part of everyday Society and are not viewed as insults. Food has been replaced with Junk Food. There is no longer 4-Star restaurants, just Fast-Food and Microwavable snacks. The marquee restaurant is called Butt-F***ers ( Fuddruckers to us). These eating habits have caused people to look Doughy (Soft and Fat).clothing has also had to change with the times. Suits and slacks have been replaced with T-Shirts and Nylon pants, covered with advertisements. Basically, if you woke up in the Idiocracy future, you wouldn't be shocked. It is everything that takes place now, just after 500 years of progression.Both Joe and Rita find themselves the smartest people alive. Joe is tasked with saving the world and Rita ends up trying to save Joe from those who he is trying to help. Maya Rudolph really plays her character well. Which must be pretty easy for her seeing as she has been on SNL for years and years. I couldn't stop laughing at her repeated worries that her former pimp would travel through time to get his money. It's just the simple things like this that make you want to watch the movie over and over again. Every time I watch it I find a new joke hidden in the background. Luke is funny because he isn't trying to be funny. That is why I didn't want to see the movie if Owen Wilson was the star. I know what to expect from Owen, but Luke isn't known for comedies.I don't want to give away everything. If you see the DVD for rent or sale, get it. Fox Movies didn't want to show Idiocracy in the theaters, so that is why you, like me, most likely didn't hear anything about it. But like Orgazmo, Idiocracy is a hidden gem. A movie that pushes boarders just enough to keep it edgy, but not enough to warrant a boycott.

reviewText: Being a fan of Mike Judge's Office Space, I was drawn to this movie.  I was never a big fan of his animated stuff, but so far his live action track record is superb.  The concept is quite simple.  The military calls on Luke Wilson and Maya Rudolph to test out their hibernation project due to their extreme average-ness.  They were only meant to be suspended in time for one year, but after the project gets shut down they find themselves waking up 500 years later, where idiots rule the world due to de-evolution as a result of years and years of hillbillies incestuously breeding.  Wilson's "average Joe" character has now become the smartest man in the world by default.The world has become overrun with mass consumerism and popular franchises turned into whore houses.  Our cultural obsessions with sex and violence has reached an all time high.  A Gatorade-type energy drink has replaced water entirely.  The President of the United States is an ex-wrestler porn star.  It's the downfall of society in every way imaginable.Idiocracy had so many jokes packed into it that I had to rewind it a few times to catch what I missed in the background.  There's so many visual gags in every location that I'm sure the art department had fun creating this idiot proof world.  The laughs per minute factor was very high as they just keep throwing joke after joke at you.  Some of them miss but the majority of them hit for me.Wilson plays the perfect straight man in an outrageous setting.  It was important to his character that they make him seem smart compared to his surroundings, but not too smart, and it's easy to put yourself in his place as he's one of the only characters that can form a complete sentence.  He still has his shortcomings but he's the perfect protagonist.  I had a bad feeling about Dax Shepard as I could not stand him in Employee of the Month, but I suppose he works better as an idiot in this movie (a lot less acting required) and he did make me laugh more than expected.Even though this movie is full of idiots, it is not intended for them.  I think there's a lot of smart humor and underlying themes to be found beneath the surface.  The social commentary this movie makes can be somewhat over the top but that's what makes it so funny is how far they push it.  There are plenty of moments that felt like an animated comedy and I think the movie would have really played well in animation, but live action with cartoony elements works great too.  There are some who will find this reality far too outlandish, but there's plenty of subtle jokes mixed in as well if you're paying attention.Don't be an idiot and overlook this as nothing more than cheap stupid laughs.  There is plenty of thought behind it if you're in the right frame of mind.  Also worth it for one of the funniest twist endings ever.

reviewText: The point was made in the first 3 minutes of the movie, and from there to the end, tiring repetitions of stereotypes that are just as silly as the people it attempts to satirize.The point isn't new, either.  Plato foresaw the direction of our society is going over 3,000 years ago. In a democracy, when everyone's vote counts the same, the advantage will go to the intellectual bottom rung, because they compose the biggest number.  C students will always vastly outnumber A+ students.  People with no musical sense or education will buy Justin Bieber, and they will always outnumber those who buy Beethoven.  In a modern democratic society, the less educated class are politically empowered, and therefore economically empowered.  With the economic empowerment of the less educated comes general cultural decline.  This is not to say I oppose democracy, but the point has been made and repeated ad nauseam for 3,000+ years.  What I'm saying is that we should know there IS a price to pay for having democracy, and we should accept the package deal if we choose that package.Many will be quick to point out that it wasn't as bad 50 years ago, although we were a democracy.  But our society wasn't as democratic 50 years ago.  Think about the purchasing power that teenagers had 50 years ago compared to today, and that will explain the popularity of certain music.  Think about the openness our society had toward certain people compared to today.  Today, success is much more attainable for people of lower educational or economic backgrounds, which is great.  But coming with that package is the perceived dominance of perceived stupidity.  Elite culture has not disappeared; in fact, from my personal experience, its quality has continued to improve.  They are just harder to find because they are now, more than ever, greatly outnumbered by other groups that did not have a chance to be heard 50 years ago.The jokes in this movie are old and way too obvious.  The fast food, the urban manners and language, the consumerism, the rednecks. I kept waiting for a fresh plot to form or a new joke to be made.  None was, but even if any, I was uneasy about the stereotyping of urban and rural populations.  Just because they are not the cultural elite does not mean they have to be lumped together with stupidity.  To me, laughing at such platitudes is just as much a representation of cultural decline.  That is the irony of it all.

This is a man not much brighter than the people of "Idiocracy", ignorant, uneducated, and seemingly proud of it.I have little interest in rock, but was wildly impressed with the way "Beavis & Butt-head" so unflinchingly catalogued the decline of Western civilization (or American society, at least). "Idiocracy" nicely expands Mike Judge's growing catalog of that decline.Idiocracy's conceit is that, as stupid people are more likely to have children than intelligent people, the world's population will inevitably move in the direction of total dunderheadedness. This is not genetically plausible (ever heard of "reversion to the mean"?), and it's contradicted by the presence of a lot of high-technology hardware, but no mind. The point is that the idea isn't as important as what you do with it. And Judge does plenty.The richness of Judge's "confederacy of dunces" is striking. Particularly notable is the utter vulgarity of social behavior, as if one of the fundamental elements of stupidity is a lack of respect and common courtesy. * And anyone who speaks clearly is a fag.Judge's direction is spot-on. It would have been so easy to play the characters as caricatures, but our future selves are believably stupid and self-absorbed. There's never any sense that we're seeing actors /pretending/ to be dumb (qv, of Jack Nicholson in "Prizzi's Honor" or Dustin Hoffman in "Rain Man"). Dax Shepard, as Frito, Joe's incompetent attorney, gives a truly remarkable performance that, in a just world, would have gotten him an Oscar nomination.At a terse 84 minutes, "Idiocracy" ends before wearing out its welcome. And Judge's dystopia is so richly imagined that you'll have to watch two or three times, your finger poised over the pause button, to catch everything.It is no surprise that Fox showed this film in five theaters, then pulled it. Granted, preview audiences hated it. Does that prove anything? Well, it shows that Fox management is even more stupid than the preview audienes.My highest recommendation. Unreseveredly recommended.PS: I watched it last night (5/29/2011). As funny as ever. We really need a Blu-ray edition. reviewText: As previous viewers have noted, this is essentially a comic remake of the classic C. M. Kornbluth short story "The Marching Morons," which you should read immediately. But while the intent here is primarily satiric, it's no less unsettling. Let's face it, the dumbed-down world depicted in the film exists right now -- the yahoo anti-intellectualism, the automatic homophobia, the glorification of the lowest common denominator -- it's all around us today. Worse, it's praised by political pundits & cultural critics who fear anything more complex than a sound bite or bumper sticker slogan, who promote "intelligent design" & other junk science over genuine science in our schools, who prefer infotainment & empty bloviating over incisive, in-depth reporting. (Note how Fox Studios buried the film, perhaps due to its scathingly accurate portrayal of Fox "News" & its happily unthinking audience.)So why four stars instead of five? The film, while short, drags in a few places, offering some wonderfully satiric ideas but not always following through on them. I enjoyed it, and it made me think, but it also left me feeling as if more could have been done with it. For example, it would have been interesting to see the state of religion in this dystopian future, or the fate of libraries.Still, it has an important point to make, and enough hilarious (if sadly true to life) ideas to make it well worth watching. Just make sure you follow Joe's advice when the film is over & read a book!

reviewText: "There was a time when movies had plots. So you knew who's [...] it was, and why it was farting."Idiocracy presents a future America (the year 2505) in which an average military guy from 2005(Luke Wilson) is put into a hibernation unit for the army and taken out 500 years later to find that he is the smartest guy in the country.The main theme of Idiocracy is incredibly relevant at this point in America's history. Humans have no natural predators, medical discoveries have extended people's lives, and it does seem that our culture is increasingly worshipping ignorance. (Look at Paris Hilton, Jessica Simpson, or any reality tv show, for examples of this). Idiocracy makes the case that in the future, we will not in fact be smarter, but will be dumber, because of the dumbing down of society that we are experiencing now.The movie is thought-provoking, but in the South Park way, where you don't feel as if you're being preached at or talked down to. And if you are stupid, you can still laugh at the fart jokes, although they come with a touch of irony in this film.The main drawback of this movie is it seems like it was a bit ambitious for the budget it had. A lot of the scenery looks very cartoony (and this may have been the intention), but it takes away from the story. Also, the DVD doesn't offer much by way of special features: just 5 deleted scenes.Overall, though, the entire movie is funny and the laughs keep coming. I have no idea why Fox wouldn't want to put out a marketing campaign for this movie and release it to a broader range of people, but it could stem from the reality of what's being portrayed in the film. Namely, Fox doesn't want to lose it's stupid viewers by mocking them in a film.
